Ask HN: How do you solve the domain registration, custom email circular problem
text: I'm looking to transition from gmail to a paid vendor (ex: Fastmail). However, as suggested in HN multiple times, I want an email with a custom domain name. However, the domain registrars like Namecheap will require an email for registration. What email to use for registration and what if I lose that email access (Gmail block). Ideally, looks like I will need 2 domains registered at 2 separate registrars and 2 separate email providers for cross-registering. Is there a simpler/cheaper way to solve this problem?

title: Ask HN: How do you handle the awkward 10 minutes at the end of a bad interview?
text: This is something I'm not sure to handle as both the interviewer and interviewee. Bad interviews happen. It can be for any reason, but what do you do when you get to the 10 minutes at the end of the interview and parties know that the interview went badly and will result in a no-hire decision?

SaaS Pricing
text:
Hi everyone, everything fine?

I'm from another country and I have a healthtech. I just finished my MVP and I have a lot of questions about the price of my product.

My startup is B2C and helps people organize their medical lives by having them put all their medical data in the app, such as files, exams, medicines, vaccines and other medical information. My app is similar to MyChart and Cerner, but in my country this type of service does not exist

I'm not sure how to price my service as I use AWS and the more user use and attach files the worse it will be for me, the more he attach information to the application the more expensive it will be for me.

Among the pricing possibilities, the one I like the most are the plans, something very similar to the Spotify and Netflix plans. I even thought about pricing by usage, the more documents attached to the app, the more the user pays, but this type of pricing will make users not put a lot of medical information in the app.

I would like to have a fair price, but that doesn't hurt me. I can't put a price of X and my user cost me 2X.

title: Ask HN: Advice on a legacy database migration project?
text:
I'm writing a blog post that aims to share real-world wisdom about what's involved in a legacy database migration. If we do this right, we'll curate advice that can help save someone else the pain you went through -- or guide them to repeat the things that worked out well.

Maybe it'll come out as "7 things you should know before you start a legacy database migration." Or "tales of the lost." Let's find out.

The key bit: What advice would you give to someone who's about to embark on a legacy database migration? ....and why is THAT the advice you offer?

Now, tell me your own story: What was the project? What did you expect to happen... and what actually did? That is, what did you think would be hard... and was it? What did you learn from the experience? What were you proud of? What do you never want to experience again?

DO include the technology just to make the details make sense; it's fine with me if this was a shift from Oracle to Postgres, though I may file off product names because this is about PROCESS and not brand affinity. Also give me the business context: You worked at a huge financial services firm that was still using a 20-year-old database where the source code was lost, or it was a ma-n-pa retail business whose data was stuck in dBase II and nobody knew it any more. Give me an idea of when it was, as well; 20 years ago is fine because the point is the lessons learned and THEY don't change.

If nothing else, we can all relive our pain. That's healing, right?
